abstract: Genomic typing for HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 was performed for 50 patients with dermatitis herpetiformis and 290 healthy blood donors. Genes encoding DQ (alpha 1*0501, beta 1*02) were carried by 43 (86%) patients and 72 (25%) controls. Of the remaining seven patients, six (12% of all patients) carried genes encoding the DQ dimer (alpha 1*03, beta 1*0302). These HLA associations are very similar to those observed in patients with celiac disease. We therefore conclude that dermatitis herpetiformis and celiac disease are associated with the same HLA-DQ alpha beta variant.

abstract: The role of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 heterodimer (DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201) in presenting gluten peptides to effector T cells has been well documented in celiac disease (CD). Because HLA-DQ2 is carried on DR3 haplotypes due to linkage disequilibrium, such haplotypes are more frequently encountered in patients with autoimmune diseases. This study analyzed 35 north Indian children younger than 15 years of age who were diagnosed with CD according to the ESPGAN criteria, which included histological changes in duodenal biopsies, clinical response to gluten withdrawal, and the presence of anti-endothelin antibodies. HLA class I and class II alleles were identified by PCR-specific primers, sequence-specific oligonucleotide probes, and reverse transcriptase molecular techniques. Statistically significant positive association of disease with HLA-DRB1*03 (94.2% vs. 22.1% in controls, chi(2) = 73.4, p = 7.54E-11), and negative association with DRB1*15 (chi(2) ) = 7.4 , p = 6.5E-03) and DRB1*13 alleles were observed. HLA-DQB1*0201 was observed in all 35 patients (100%), while the presence of DQ2 heterodimer alpha(0)beta(0) occurred in 97.1% of CD patients (31.4% in double dose, 65.7% in single dose) It revealed a significant deviation from healthy controls (chi(2) = 102.08, p = 7.56E-11). Further analysis revealed the involvement of several DR3+ve haplotypes with CD in Indians, of which A26-B8-DR3 was the most common DR3 haplotype among patients (34.28%, chi(2) = 40.57, p = 2.65E- 10) followed by Ax-B21-DR3 (11.4%) (chi(2) = 13.8, p = 2E-04) and the classic Caucasian haplotype A1-B8-DR3 (5.7%). The former two haplotypes are characteristic of Asian Indians and are involved in the development of CD. We conclude that the high-risk DR3 haplotypes that play a critical role in the development of CD are unique to Asian Indians. Detailed analysis of these haplotypes in Indian patients with autoimmune diseases may help in understanding the influence of other involved genes within the major histocompatibility complex.

abstract: From 1991 to 1998, we vaccinated 4835 neonates against hepatitis B virus (HBV) and monitored their humoral response to the recombinant vaccine. In a sample of 184 of these children, we studied the association between HLA class I and II genomic polymorphisms and humoral response to vaccine and the association between immune response and disease. A subgroup of 96 children also underwent HLA class III typing (C4A and C4B). Four levels of humoral response have been identified, each with peculiar major histocompatibility complex (MHC) restriction. Different HLA products appear to act as agonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02) or antagonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02, and HLA-DRB1(*)11, DQB1(*)0301) in lowering humorality. Response to hepatitis B virus vaccine. The group of responders was characterized by a lack of “non-responder” alleles rather than by the presence of specific “responder” alleles. Tolerance to hepatitis B virus peptides may have clinical implications and may be a marker in children who have a genetic risk for autoimmune diseases. In fact, many poor responders carried two to four HLA-DQ alpha beta variants leading to insulin-dependent diabetes and celiac disease. Two true non-responders suffered from allergies and two slow responders had transient episodes of hyperglycemia.

abstract: The possibility that genetic susceptibility to celiac disease (CD) is influenced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene polymorphisms has been repeatedly raised. To date, this has only been investigated in case-control studies and results have been contradictory. In order to avoid any potential ethnic mismatch between patients and controls, we approached this issue by studying 71 celiac families, establishing parental haplotypes and comparing CD haplotypes versus control haplotypes (so-called AFBAC or affected family controls). We used DNA-based approaches to screen HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 alleles, TNFalpha promoter polymorphisms, and TNFa and b microsatellites. A guanine to adenine polymorphism at position -308 in the TNFalpha gene promoter region was found to be associated with CD where the TNF-308A allele appeared significantly in frequency in CD haplotypes, and this was shown to be independent of the association between CD and DRB1 alleles. *0301,DQA1*0501,DQB1*0201. Our results suggest that at least one other gene, in addition to the known association of CD with HLA class II, has a susceptibility role to this disease. This must be either TNFalpha or another polymorphic gene at the telomeric end of the HLA class III region.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis is a common disease of the central nervous system in which the interplay between inflammatory and neurodegenerative processes usually results in intermittent neurological disorder followed by a progressive accumulation of disability. Epidemiological studies have shown that genetic factors are primarily responsible for the significant increase in disease recurrence in relatives of affected individuals, and systematic attempts to identify links in multiplex families have confirmed that variation within the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) exerts the greatest influence. Individual influence on risk. Modestly powered genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the identification of more than 20 additional risk loci and shown that multiple variants exerting modest individual effects have a major role in disease susceptibility. Most of the genetic architecture underlying susceptibility to the disease remains to be determined, and is expected to require analysis of sample sizes that exceed the numbers currently available for individual research groups. In a collaborative GWAS study including 9772 cases of European origin collected by 23 research groups working in 15 different countries, we replicated almost all previously proposed associations and identified at least 29 new susceptibility loci. Within the MHC we have refined the identity of the HLA-DRB1 risk alleles and confirmed that variation in the HLA-A gene underlies the independent protective effect attributable to the class I region. Immuneologically relevant genes are overrepresented among those genes close to the identified loci, especially T helper cell differentiation in MS pathogenesis.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system in which a restricted cellular immune response is observed. In order to determine whether these T-cell responses are likely to be antigen-specific particularly with respect to myelin basic protein (MBP), we analyzed T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangements directly from MS brain plaques, using reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction. transcribed messenger RNA (RNA), and compared them with TCR clones for MBP-specific T cells described previously from an MS and experimental allergic encephalomyelitis murine model. Rearranged V beta 5.2 genes were detected in the brains of all patients with HLA DRB1*1501, DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401. Beta V beta 5,2-D beta-J sequences in MS brain plaques revealed five isoforms. One common element was identical to that described for the VDJ region of the V beta 5.2 T cell clone. This clone was from an MS patient that was HLA DRB1*1501, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401, and was cytotoxic toward targets containing the MBP peptide. 89-106 (Ref. 1). The deduced amino acid sequence of the VDJ rearrangement, Leu-Arg-Gly, has also been described in murine T cells cloned from experimental allergic encephalomyelitis lesions, which is specific for the MBP peptide 87-99 (ref. 2). VDJ sequences with this MBP loop specificity account for a significant fraction (40%) of TCR V beta 5.2(D)N rearrangements in MS lesions. The ability of rat T cells with these VDJ sequences to cause experimental allergic encephalomyelitis and the prevalence of such sequences in human demyelinated lesions suggest that T cells with rearranged TCRs may be critical in MS.

abstract: There is a striking gradient in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis (MS), but exceptions in Mediterranean Europe and northern Scandinavia, and some systematic reviews, suggest that the gradient may be an artifact. The authors sought to evaluate the relationship between MS prevalence and latitude through meta-regression. Studies were obtained from online databases, reference mining, and author referral. Prevalence estimates were age-standardized for the European population in 2009. Analyzes were performed by random-effects meta-regression, weighted with the inverse of the within-study variance. The authors included 650 prevalence estimates from 321 peer-reviewed studies; Of these, 239 were standardized by age, and 159 provided sex-specific data. The researchers found a significant positive association (change in prevalence by degree of latitude) between age-standardized prevalence (1.04, p<0.001) and latitude that diminished at higher latitudes. Adjusting for year of spread strengthened the association with latitude (2.60, p<0.001). The inverse gradient was reversed in the Italian region when adjusting for MS-associated HLA-DRB1 allele distributions. Adjusting for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies did not significantly change the gradient in Europe. Adjusting for some potential sources of bias did not affect the observed associations. This most comprehensive review of MS prevalence to date confirmed a statistically significant positive relationship between MS prevalence and latitude globally. The exceptions to phasing in the Italian region and northern Scandinavia are likely the result of genetic, behavioral and cultural differences. The persistence of a positive gradient in Europe after adjustment for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies strongly supports the role of environmental factors that vary with latitude, the most prominent candidates being ultraviolet radiation (UVR)/vitamin D.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex trait in which allelic variation in the MHC class II region exerts the strongest influence on genetic risk. Epidemiological data in MS provide strong evidence that environmental factors act at the population level to influence the unusual geographic distribution of this disease. Increasing evidence points to sunlight or vitamin D as a major environmental factor in its aetiology. We hypothesized that this environmental filter might interact with inherited factors and sought responsive regulatory elements in the MHC class II region. Sequence analysis identified a single MHC vitamin D response element (VDRE) to the promoter region of HLA-DRB1. Sequencing of this promoter in more than 1000 chromosomes of HLA-DRB1 homozygotes showed absolute conservation of the putative VDRE over HLA-DRB1*15 haplotypes. In contrast, there was striking variation among non-MS haplotypes. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific recruitment of vitamin D receptors to the VDRE in the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter, which was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments using lymphoblasts homozygous for HLA-DRB1*15. Transient transfection using a luciferase reporter assay demonstrated a functional role for this VDRE. B cells transiently transfected with the HLA-DRB1*15 gene promoter showed increased expression upon stimulation with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (P = 0.002) that was lost when the VDRE was deleted or with the homologous “VDRE” sequence found in non-HLA haplotypes. -DRB1 associated with MS. Flow cytometric analysis showed a specific increase in cell surface expression of HLA-DRB1 upon vitamin D addition only in lymphoblasts bearing HLA-DRB1*15. This study further points to vitamin D as a strong environmental candidate in MS by demonstrating direct functional interaction with a key locus that determines genetic susceptibility. These findings support a relationship between the main epidemiological and genetic features of this disease with major practical implications for studies of disease mechanism and prevention.
cot: The abstract is directly relevant and provides strong evidence supporting the hypothesis that there is an interaction between multiple sclerosis (MS) and the HLA-DRB1 gene. A score given of 1 accurately represents relevance. Several elements in the summary confirm the strength of this interaction:  1. **Genetic focus on HLA-DRB1**: The study specifically targets the HLA-DRB1 gene, which is known to be closely linked to multiple sclerosis. It should be noted that allelic variation in the MHC class II region, where HLA-DRB1 is located, has a significant impact on genetic risk for MS.  2. **Environmental interactions**: The abstract discusses the role of environmental factors, especially sunlight or vitamin D, which are hypothesized to interact with genetic factors such as HLA-DRB1. This highlights not only genetic predisposition but also the interaction between genes and environment in the pathogenesis of MS.  3. **Experimental validation**: Several experimental approaches are used to demonstrate the functional involvement of HLA-DRB1 in MS:    - **Sequence analysis**: The vitamin D response element (VDRE) specifically locates in the promoter region of HLA-DRB1*15, a variant closely associated with MS.    - ** Electrophoretic mobility shift assays and chromatin immunoprecipitation **: demonstrated specific recruitment of the vitamin D receptor to a specific VDRE, further linking the environmental factor (vitamin D) to gene expression.    - **Luciferase Reporter Assay**: Validates the functional role of the VDRE, suggesting that vitamin D can directly affect HLA-DRB1 gene activity.    - **Expression studies**: Show that cells containing the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter show increased expression upon stimulation with vitamin D, which is critical in understanding the modulation of immune responses in MS.  4. **Clinical and Epidemiological Significance**: Differences in VDRE between different HLA-DRB1 haplotypes, particularly between MS-associated and non-MS-associated haplotypes, provide a strong genetic link to the unique geographic and distributional patterns observed in MS Multi.  In summary, the summary effectively demonstrates a significant interaction between MS and the HLA-DRB1 gene through detailed genetic and environmental pathway analysis, confirming the hypothesis and justifying a significance score of 1.

abstract: Throughout the usual LDL cholesterol range in Western populations, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, in such populations, reducing LDL cholesterol may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of initial cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40-80 years) with coronary artery disease, other arterial-occlusive disease or diabetes were randomly allocated to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily (median compliance: 85%) or placebo Matched (average statin use without study: 17%). ). Analyzes are first performed for specific events, comparing all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo. These “intention-to-treat” comparisons evaluate the effects of about two-thirds (85% minus 17%) taking a statin during the scheduled 5-year treatment period, which resulted in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (About two-thirds of the effect of actual use of 40 mg of simvastatin daily). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subgroup analyses), with subcategories for cancer and other major morbidity. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin assigned vs. 1,507 [14.7%] among 10,267 placebo assigned; P = 0.0003), due to a very significant relative reduction of 18%. (SE 5) in coronary mortality (587 [5.7%] vs. 707 [6.9%]; P = 0.0005), and a marginally significant reduction in other vascular deaths (194 [1.9%] vs. 230 [2.2%]; P = 0.07), and a non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality (547 [5.3%] versus 570 [5.6%]; P = 0.4). There were highly significant reductions of about a quarter in the first event rate for nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] versus 1212 [11.8%]; P < 0.0001), for nonfatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%]). vs 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001), and for coronary or non-coronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a significant 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19-28) reduction in event rate (2033 [19.8%] versus 2585 [25.2%] of affected individuals; p < 0.0001 ). During the first year, the reduction in major vascular events was not significant, but was subsequently very large during each separate year. The relative reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in every subgroup of participants studied, including: those who were not diagnosed with coronary artery disease and who had cerebrovascular disease, had peripheral artery disease, or They had diabetes; Men and women separately; Those aged 70 or over at entry; And - especially - even those with LDL cholesterol less than 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL), or total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefits of simvastatin were additional to those of other cardiac treatments. The excess annual risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or on hospitalization for any reason other than vascular. Adding simvastatin to existing therapies safely results in significant additional benefits for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the rates of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for non-compliance, actual use of this system would likely reduce these rates by about a third. Hence, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, taking simvastatin for 5 years would prevent about 70-100 people per 1000 from suffering at least one of these major vascular events (and longer treatment should to more benefits). The magnitude of the 5-year benefit is based primarily on these individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not on blood lipid concentrations alone.
cot: The abstract presented was scored as 1, indicating its relevance for evaluating the hypothesis that simvastatin interacts with peripheral artery disease (PAD). The following is a detailed explanation supporting this recording:  1. **Specific indication for peripheral artery disease**: The abstract clearly includes patients with peripheral artery disease among the study participants. This mention confirms that the effect of simvastatin on this specific group of patients was taken into account in the study, directly linking the drug to the disease of interest in the hypothesis.  2. **Broad participant profile**: The study was not limited to individuals with peripheral artery disease; Patients with other cardiovascular and related diseases were also included. However, the inclusion of patients with PAD makes the abstract relevant to the hypothesis specifically because it provides data for this subgroup.  3. **Presentation of treatment efficacy**: The summary explains the effects of simvastatin on major vascular events, including those that may be associated with peripheral artery disease, such as nonfatal or fatal stroke and coronary or noncoronary revascularization. Reports indicate a significant reduction in these events among the treated group compared to the placebo group, suggesting a beneficial interaction of simvastatin with vascular disease including peripheral artery disease.  4. **Peripheral Artery Disease Outcome Measures**: Reported outcomes, such as reductions in rates of revascularization and major vascular events, are relevant to PAD management and prognosis. Since peripheral artery disease involves vascular pathways similar to other cardiovascular conditions, improvements in these indicators are directly relevant.  5. **Statistical and clinical significance**: The study highlights statistically significant results with respect to the primary outcomes. A consistent reduction in vascular events is observed across subgroups of participants, including those with peripheral artery disease, confirming the effectiveness of simvastatin in this particular group.  6. **Implications for the treatment of peripheral atherosclerosis**: By demonstrating that simvastatin significantly reduces the risk of major vascular events in high-risk patients, including those with peripheral atherosclerosis, the abstract supports the hypothesis that Simvastatin has a beneficial interaction with the mechanisms and progression of peripheral artery disease.  Considering these points, the summary is very relevant and supports the evaluation of the hypothesis regarding the interaction between simvastatin and peripheral artery disease, justifying the degree of importance presented.

abstract: Although treatment of myocardial overload effectively reduces death resulting from the development of heart failure, it is not known whether remission of progressive coronary artery disease resulting from lipid-lowering therapy will prevent the onset and consequences of heart failure in patients with no previous symptoms. For heart failure. In the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study, 4444 patients with coronary heart disease without evidence of heart failure were randomized to placebo (n = 2223) or simvastatin 20-40 mg (n = 2221) and followed for more than 5 years. Among patients who received placebo, 228 (10.3%) were diagnosed with heart failure during follow-up evaluation compared with 184 (8.3%) of patients who received simvastatin (P < .015). The mortality rate was 31.9% in the placebo group and 25.5% in the simvastatin group among patients who developed heart failure. These compare with 9.2 and 6.6%, respectively, among patients without heart failure. There were 45 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the placebo group and 23 in the simvastatin (NS) group. Patients who developed heart failure were more likely to have recurrent myocardial infarction and to have a history of diabetes, peripheral artery disease, and hypertension compared to patients who did not develop congestive heart failure. Long-term prophylaxis with simvastatin reduces the incidence of heart failure in a group of patients with coronary heart disease without previous evidence of congestive heart failure.
cot: The submitted abstract was rated as relevant (score 1) to evaluate the hypothesis that simvastatin has an interaction with peripheral artery disease (PAD). Below is a detailed explanation of this classification:  1. **Context of Simvastatin Use**: The abstract discusses a study involving long-term use of simvastatin in patients with coronary heart disease but without previous symptoms of congestive heart failure. Simvastatin, a statin drug, is primarily used to manage cholesterol and has effects on cardiovascular disease, which often overlaps with conditions such as peripheral artery disease.  2. **Association with cardiovascular disease risk factors**: Study highlights that patients who developed heart failure (a condition linked to a broader range of cardiovascular disease, including peripheral artery disease) were more likely to have risk factors Suffering from various cardiovascular diseases. Including diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, and high blood pressure. This association establishes a relevant context in which the effect of simvastatin on one cardiovascular condition may inferentially extend to other conditions such as peripheral artery disease.  3. **Implications for Peripheral Artery Disease**: Peripheral artery disease is closely linked to other forms of cardiovascular disease because it shares common risk factors such as atherosclerosis, which simvastatin directly targets by lowering blood cholesterol levels. The mention of peripheral artery disease among the risk factors in patients who develop heart failure suggests a pathway by which simvastatin may influence PAD outcomes.  4. **Statistical significance of results**: The summary reports significant results for heart failure incidence and mortality rates between the treatment and placebo groups. While these data specifically address heart failure, the mechanisms of action of simvastatin and the shared risk profiles between heart failure and peripheral artery disease make these findings indirectly relevant to peripheral artery disease.  5. **Broader Effects on Vascular Health**: Improvements in cardiac outcomes with simvastatin therapy, as demonstrated by reduced diagnoses of heart failure and lower mortality rates, support the potential beneficial effects of this drug on overall vascular health. This includes potential applications for managing or preventing complications in peripheral artery disease.  By considering the abstract's discussion of simvastatin in a context that includes peripheral artery disease among the risk factors for heart failure, it becomes relevant to evaluate broader drug interactions with peripheral artery disease. Thus, the summary supports the hypothesis regarding the interaction of simvastatin with peripheral artery disease, providing implications for how the drug may beneficially affect peripheral artery disease through its cardiovascular effects.
